_prev_prog_3.PC_OtherType: DOT Security Plan, Registered with CSAT thru DHS
_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: Detectors include smoke and flash for several of the process areas.
_prev_prog_3.Description:
1. ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

CLEAN HARBORS ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM IS BASED ON BOTH OSHA'S PSM PROGRAM AND EPA'S RMP LEVEL 3 PREVENTION PROGRAM.  THE PSM PROGRAMS HAVE BEEN IN PLACE AND EFFECTIVELY USED SINCE 1992.  THERE ARE TWO PARTS TO THE PROGRAM.  THE FIRST IS THE PLANT WIDE PROGRAM.  THE SECOND IS THE CHEMICALS-SPECIFIC ACTIONS WITHIN THE SITE PROGRAM.  CLEAN HARBOS HAS A WELL TRAINED EMPLOYEE FIRE BRIGADE, EMERGENCY RESPONSE (HAZMAT) TEAM, CONFINED SPACE RESCUE TEAM, AND MEDICAL FIRST AID TEAM.  WE CAN USE THE CITY OF EL DORADO'S FIRE DEPARTMENT FOR FIRE FIGHTING BACK-UP. 

1.1.    GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM   

THE FACILITY-WIDE PREVENTION PROGRAM IS USED FOR ALL OPERATIONS.  AN OVERVIEW OF THE PREVENTION PROGRAM IS LISTED BELOW:

CLEAN HARBORS HAS DETAILED PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION ON EACH OF ITS OPERATIONS THIS INCLUDES MSDS AS WELL AS WASTE PROFILES, EQUIPMENT MANUALS, P&IDS, ETC. 

DETAILED OPERATING PROCEDURES ARE KEPT IN A DOCUMENT MAINTENANCE SYSTEM, QSI.  QSI IS INTEGRAL INTO THE MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE FOR ALL OPERATIONS ON SITE.  TRAINING IS THE BACKBONE OF EMPLOYEE KNOWLEDGE, JOB OPERATIONS AND IS ONGOING IN EACH AREA.  EMPLOYEE TRAINING IN OPERATIONS AND MAINTENANCE EMPHASIZES AWARENESS OF THE HAZARDOUS AND TOXIC PROPERTIES OF ALL CHEMICALS USED, OR HANDLED. 

MAINTENANCE AND PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE ARE USED FOR ALL OPERATIONS MAKING MECHANICAL INTEGRITY A PART OF EACH PIECE OF EQUIPMENT. 

INCIDENT INVESTIGATIONS OF ACCIDENTS ENSURE LEARNING FROM EACH EVENT AS WELL AS CORRECT THE ROOT CAUSE(S) OF THE INCIDENT. 

EMPLOYEES PARTICIPATE IN ALL ASPECTS OF THE DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF OUR HEALTH, SAFETY AND ENVIRONMENTAL PROGRAMS.  EMPLOYEES PARTICIPATE IN THE SAFETY COMMITTEE, EMERGENCY RESPONSE TEAMS; PROCESS HAZARDS ANALYSIS TEAMS, PROCEDURE WRITING AND SAFETY CHECK PROGRAM.  ALL PSI IS AVAILABLE TO EMPLOYEES. 

SAFE WORK PRACTICES ARE USED THROUGHOUT THE FACILITY INCLUDING:  1) HOT WORK PERMITS, 2) LOCK-OUT TAG-OUT PERMITS, 3) VESSEL ENTRY PERMITS, 4) SITE SECURITY, AND 5) BREAKING INTO CHEMICAL LINES PROCEDURES. 

CONTRACTORS MUST MEET CLEAN HARBORS HIGH SAFETY AND TECHNICAL STANDARDS AS PART OF SELECTION AND ONGOING EVALUATIONS.  IN ADDITION, CLEAN HARBORS DEMANDS TRAINING OF CONTRACTORS TO THE FACILITY'S STANDARDS. 

1.2.    CHEMICALS SPECIFIC RESPONSE PROGRAM 

1.2.1.    Chemicals-Specific Operating Safety Information

CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION FEATURES OF THE FACILITY INCLUDE: THE POLICIES AND PROCEDURES LISTED ABOVE AND THOSE OF THE STORAGE AND INCINERATION PLANT SPECIFIC OPERATION PROGRAM.  THESE INCLUDE:

1.2.2.    Specific procedures for the management of the Chemicals process. 

COMPLETION OF A PRE-STARTUP SAFETY REVIEW PRIOR TO STARTUP OF THE MODIFIED CHEMICALS SYSTEM IS REQUIRED.   

SPECIFIC EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROCEDURES FOR CHEMICAL RELEASES AS OUTLINED BELOW UNDER BOTH OPERATING PROCEDURES AND IN THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROCEDURES.  SEE THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE. 

SPECIFIC TRAINING IN THE PROPERTY HAZARDS, HANDLING REQUIREMENTS, AND LEAK REPAIR FOR CHEMICALS IS REQUIRED. 

FINALLY, THE DETAILS OF BOTH FACILITY AND EQUIPMENT DESIGN ARE KEY TO THE SAFE OPERATIONS OF THE CHEMICALS SYSTEM.

1.2.3.    Facility Design

THE CONTAINERIZED CHEMICAL WASTE STORAGE AREA IS LOCATED IN AN OPEN AIR AREA WAREHOUSE.  THE WAREHOUSE STORAGE AREA AND CONTROL ROOM ARE EQUIPPED WITH NATURAL AND FORCED VENTILATION SYSTEM, RESPECTIVELY.  ALL BULK CHEMICAL TANKS ARE LOCATED IN VARIOUS OPEN AREAS.  EACH TANK IS PADDED WITH NITROGEN TO INERT THE VAPOR SPACE.  EACH TANK IS LOCATED WITHIN SPILL CONTAINMENT.  THE SPECIAL HANDLING BUILDING HAS A FIRE MONITORS AND ALARMS.  THERE ARE FIRE DETECTORS AND EXTINGUISHING SYSTEMS IN THE DETACHED STORAGE BUILDINGS SPECIALLY DESIGNED FOR THE OXIDIZER AND WATER REACTIVE CHEMICALS.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
CLEAN HARBORS EL DORADO LLC

INCINERATION FACILITY

RISK MANAGEMENT PROGRAM 

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



1.    EXECUTIVE SUMMARY INTRODUCTION 

Clean Harbors operates a hazardous waste treatment, storage, and disposal facility in an industrial area east of El Dorado.  The address is 309 American Circle, El Dorado, Union County, Arkansas.  The general commercial function of the facility is to thermally treat (incinerate) hazardous and non-regulated materials and render the incinerator residues acceptable for disposal at regulated Subtitle C landfills.  The facility also acts as a transfer station for wastes not amenable to thermal treatment.

Clean Harbors facility is operated by the Clean Harbor Staff.  The Facility has quantities of regulated hazardous chemicals above the EPA threshold, because of the highly variable nature of the chemicals received, Clean Harbors will use predictive filing for the RMP.  Clean Harbors has a unified Risk Management Program which applies to this Facility.  Clean Harbors facility operations and policies are presented in this Plan.

1.1.    MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS 

Clean Harbors has a management system in place which is lead by the Vice President of Environmental Compliance as well as the Vice President of Health and Safety,  who oversees the implementation and on-going use of the RMP elements.  This program, along with other specific policies, eliminates and/or reduces the likelihood of a hazardous chemical release at the Facility.  An organizational chart defining the lines of authority and responsible staff is included in the Facility's RMP Process Safety Information.

1.2.    PREVENTION PROGRAM LEVEL 3 

Clean Harbors maintains policies, procedures and systems as part of their prevention program.  This program addresses each of the EPA Program Level 3-Pevention elements that are like the elements of the in-place OSHA PSM program.  RMP also has unique elements as: a management system, off-site hazards assessment, and RMP Plan submittal.  

1.3.    STATIO

NARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED AT CLEAN HARBORS ARKANSAS SITE  

 Clean Harbors El Dorado employs about 300 employees.  Clean Harbors also employs contractors and consultants for specialized tasks.

The site is owned and operated by Clean Harbors El Dorado LLC.  The facility receives hazardous wastes in many forms and container s.  The facility receives small containerized lab packs, 55 gallon drums, and totes.  The facility also receives bulk chemicals in over the road trailer vans as well as rail tankers and solids in roll off containers.

The boundaries of the RMP chemical process areas include five processes;

1.)    Warehouse receiving and storage of containerized materials,

2.)    Bulk liquid receiving, storage, and feed to the incinerator system,

3.)    Direct Burn of both tankers and cylinders to the incinerator system,

4.)    Special handling Facility where materials are repacked for incineration.  This process also includes separate storage buildings for oxidizers as well as separate storage buildings for water reactive material, and

5.)    Incinerator staging and feed system includes direct drum drops, auger shredders and direct drum pumping to the incineration system.

The boundary of the RMP process ends as the  waste materials combust within the rotary kiln and the secondary combustion chamber.

Every chemical received, stored, transferred and incinerated on site goes through at least two of the above processes.  Several chemicals can be processed through each of the five processes.  These processes are detailed in the Piping and Instrument Drawings (P&ID) and simplified block flow diagrams which are part of the Process Safety Information (PSI).  All drawings are maintained in the Facilities RMP Process Safety Information.

1.3.1.    REGULATED SUBSTANCE 

Clean Harbors receives thousands of chemicals and waste streams.  Therefore, Clean Harbors is using predictive filing for regulated substances that may exceed the EPA 40 CFR-68 rule threshold quantity

.  Clean Harbors has a waste approval and acceptance program that screens every waste before it is received on site.  Clean Harbors staff uses a computerized inventory control system to track each RMP (and PSM) chemical.  The predictive filing inventory lists 34 RMP chemicals.  Of these, 17 are flammable and 17 are toxic.  Prior to acceptance of another RMP listed chemicals above its threshold quantity, a revised RMP Plan will be submitted.  The following table of RMP chemicals includes their maximum intended inventory based on predictive filing. 



 

TABLE OF CHEMICALS AND MAXIMUM EXPECTED INVENTORY

 



2.    HAZARD ASSESSMENT

A hazard assessment was performed to determine the potential effects a release could have on the public and environment.  For toxic chemicals, the distance to the endpoint concentration the gas could travel was determined.  In addition, an estimate of the population that could be affected by a release of Chemicals was determined, and sensitive receptors such as hospitals, schools, and nursing homes were identified. The hazard assessment was conducted for each flammable and each toxic chemical.  Based on the results, two scenarios, a "worst case" flammable and a "worst case" toxic events were chosen.  Also, alternative case scenario's were conducted for each of the 34 chemicals.

The offsite consequence analyses conducted included two worst chemical release case scenarios.  The first is a worst case flammable release.  The second is a worst case toxic release scenario.  Both scenarios are defined by EPA, which states that the operator shall assume that the maximum quantity in the largest vessel is released within 10 minutes due to an unspecified failure. Clean Harbors also conducted offsite consequence analysis for alternative case scenarios.  These were based on plant experience and our recent and past process hazards analysis.  

Atmospheric dispersion modeling was performed using RMP Comp to determine the distance traveled by the chemical

s released before the concentration decreases to the toxic endpoint.  The EPA's specified endpoint for each toxic chemical was used.  The toxic endpoint defined by the American Industrial Hygiene Association (AIHA) as the maximum airborne concentration below which it is believed that nearly all individuals could be exposed for up to one hour without experiencing or developing irreversible or other serious health effects or symptoms which could impair an individualA's ability to take protective action.  The residential population within a circle with a radius corresponding to the toxic endpoint distance was defined.  To estimate the population potentially affected, Land view 6.0 was used.  This program contains the latest, 2000, US census data.  

2.1.    WORST CASE   

Atmospheric dispersion modeling for the worst case toxic scenario was performed using site specific data, EPA assumptions and criteria contained in EPA's RMP Comp Program.

Results and figures of the worst case scenarios are included in the RMP report maintained on site.

Dispersion modeling for the worst case flammable scenario was performed using sit specific data, EPA assumptions and criteria contained in the EPA's RMP Comp Program.  No off site impacts were found within the worst case endpoint.

2.2.    ALTERNATIVE CASE   

The alternative release scenario involves the failure of a vessel, tank or pipe system.  This failure was defined by plant experience and during the recent Process Hazards Analysis.  Modeling using the EPA, RMP Comp and EPA's guidance was used.  The toxic endpoint distances were determined using the following site specific variables for each of the 34 chemicals.  These variables are listed in the process safety information.  The residential population that would be impacted by this release is recorded in the process safety information.  Receptors in this area were identified as residences, schools, recreational areas, etc.

3.    ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM 

Clean Harbors acc

idental release prevention program is based on both OSHA's PSM program and EPA's RMP Level 3 prevention program.  The PSM programs have been in place and effectively used since 1992.  There are two parts to the program.  The first is the plant wide program.  The second is the chemicals-specific actions within the site program.  Clean Harbors has a well trained employee Fire Brigade, Emergency Response (HAZMAT) Team, Confined Space Rescue Team, and Medical First Aid Team.  We can use the City of El Dorado;s fire department for fire fighting back-up. 

3.1.    GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM   

The facility-wide prevention program is used for all operations.  An overview of the prevention program is listed below:

Clean Harbors has detailed process safety information on each of its operations this includes MSDS as well as waste profiles, equipment manuals, P&IDs, etc. 

Detailed operating procedures are kept in a share drive. 

Training is the backbone of employee knowledge, job operations and is ongoing in each area.  Employee training in operations and maintenance emphas awareness of the hazardous and toxic properties of all chemicals used, or handled. 

Maintenance and preventive maintenance are used for all operations making mechanical integrity a part of each piece of equipment. 

Incident investigations of accidents ensure learning from each event as well as correct the root cause(s) of the incident. 

Employees participate in all aspects of the development and implementation of our health, safety and environmental programs.  Employees participate in the safety committee, emergency response teams, process hazards analysis teams, procedure writing and safety check program.  All PSI is available to employees. 

Safe work practices are used throughout the facility including:  1) Hot Work Permits, 2) Lock-Out Tag-Out Permits, 3) Vessel Entry Permits, 4) Site Security, and 5) Breaking Into Chemical Lines procedures. 

Contractors must meet Clean Harbors h

igh safety and technical standards as part of selection and ongoing evaluations.  In addition, Clean Harbors demands training of contractors to the facility standards. 

3.2.    CHEMICALS SPECIFIC RESPONSE PROGRAM 

3.2.1.    Chemicals-Specific Operating Safety Information

Chemical-specific prevention features of the facility include: the policies and procedures listed above and those of the storage and incineration plant specific operation program.  These include:

3.2.2.    Specific procedures for the management of the Chemicals process. 

Completion of a Pre-startup Safety Review prior to startup of the modified Chemicals system.   

Specific emergency response procedures for chemical releases as outlined below under both operating procedures and in the emergency response procedures.  See the Emergency Response. 

Specific training in the property hazards, handling requirements, and leak repair for chemicals. 

Finally, the details of both facility and equipment design are key to the safe operations of the chemicals system.

3.2.3.    Facility Design

The containerized chemical waste storage area is located in an open air area warehouse.  The warehouse storage area and control room are equipped with natural and forced ventilation system, respectively.  All bulk chemical tanks are located in various open areas.  Each tank is padded with nitrogen to inert the vapor space.  Each tank is located within a spill containment.  The Special Handling Building has a fire monitors and alarms.  There are fire detectors and extinguishing systems in the detached storage buildings specially designed for the oxidizer and water reactive chemicals.

4.    INVESTIGATIVE FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY (E)Not applicable.

5.    EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM (F)

Emergency response procedures are contained in the Facility Emergency Response Policy Contingency Plan and are coordinated with the Union County LEPC as well as the El Dorado Fire Department.  The plan includes an emergency response decision tree and

a notification plan.  The Facility also has site specific emergency actions defined in the Facilities operating procedures.  Emergency response drills and evacuation drills are conducted at least annually by the safety department for each of the operating departments personnel.  Emergency operation and response procedures are also reviewed annually.  

Clean Harbors has developed an emergency response plan (in accordance with 29 CFR 1910.38) that includes provisions to evacuate employees, contractors and visitors from the facility in the event of an uncontrolled accidental release of a hazardous chemical.  Clean Harbors is also subject to OSHA's Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response (HAZWOPER) Plan regulations (29 CFR 1910.120).  Clean Harbors has developed and implemented a HAZWOPER program that includes on-site emergency responders, on-site fire brigade, fixed and mobile fire protection equipment, and fire and vapor suppression chemicals.  Training on the HAZWOPER program is conducted on annual basis to ensure employees are properly trained and ready to respond to a chemical emergency.    



In the event of an uncontrolled release of any RMP/PSM or other hazardous chemical, trained Clean Harbors personnel respond to the emergency.  The El Dorado and Union County LEPC are contacted to stand by and assist in the emergency response, if needed.  Teris has coordinated with the Union County LEPC and the local fire department on the hazard chemicals present at the facility and Clean Harbors emergency response policies.

6.    PERSONNEL 

Personnel are the key resource of Clean Harbors prevention program.  Clean Harbors employees make up the operators, maintenance staff and emergency response teams.  Clean Harbors fosters a high level of employee involvement in every aspect of the plant operations.  Including:

        Plant Safety Committee

        Invest Safety Program

        VPP Committee

        PSM/RMP Safety Teams

        Process Hazards Analysis Tea

m

        Development of the operation procedures

        Emergency Response and Rescue Teams

        HazMat, HazWopper Teams

        On-going employee training

        Fire Brigade

7.    CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY 

The following are some of the changes and improvements made to improve safety at the facility:

1) December 2014-January 2015 Installation of two fire safe building with alarms and automatic fire suppression for oxidizers. 

2) Installed temperature monitoring for kilns.

3) Installed camera monitoring systems for operations.

4) Installed duct cannons on #1 duct work.

5) Installed new employee showers in the employee complex building.
